faq.answer: We use local anaesthetic and offer conscious sedation. Most patients report mild soreness at the harvest site for 24-48 hours, easily managed with paracetamol. The injection site feels similar to a standard joint injection.
faq.question: Is the BMAC harvest painful?
How soon will I notice improvement after BMAC?
faq.answer: Expect gradual improvement from 6-12 weeks as stem cells regenerate tissue and inflammation subsides. Most patients report significant pain reduction by 3 months, with continued improvement up to 12 months.

faq.question: How long do BMAC results last?
faq.answer: Clinical studies show BMAC results can last 3-5 years or longer. Many patients avoid joint replacement surgery entirely. Annual follow-ups help monitor progress and determine if boosters would benefit you.

faq.question: Is BMAC better than PRP for joints?
faq.answer: BMAC contains stem cells and is more potent than PRP, making it ideal for severe arthritis and large tendon tears. PRP works well for mild-moderate conditions. Dr Abbas will recommend based on your imaging and condition severity.

faq.question: How much does BMAC therapy cost?
faq.answer: BMAC therapy starts from £3,450 including harvest, processing, injection, and rehab plan. The BMAC + PRP Boost package is £3,950. Consultation fee (£200) is credited toward treatment. 0% finance available.

faq.question: Can BMAC help me avoid knee replacement surgery?
faq.answer: In many cases, yes. BMAC can regenerate cartilage and significantly reduce pain, delaying or avoiding joint replacement. Success depends on arthritis severity—we'll review your imaging and give honest expectations at consultation.

faq.question: Is BMAC covered by insurance?
faq.answer: Some private health insurers cover BMAC therapy as an orthobiologic treatment. We provide detailed invoices and medical reports to support your claim. Check with your provider about regenerative medicine coverage.

faq.question: What's the recovery time after BMAC?
faq.answer: Rest for 72 hours post-procedure, then begin guided physiotherapy. Most patients return to desk work within 3-5 days. Progressive loading starts at week 2, with return to sport typically at 10-12 weeks depending on your condition.
